awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Strain-Sensing Smart Skin - a New Technology for Strain Measurement
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of strain measurement technology that uses carbon nanotubes.  Strain measurements are used in a wide variety of heavy industries, including aerospace, bridge maintenance, pipeline and chemical plant safety inspections, wind turbine monitoring, and others. Strain technologies are needed for testing critical structures and for routine maintenance inspections of infrastructure exposed to large stresses/strains. The proposed technology is a strain-sensing smart skin, a non-contact, laser-based sensor that uses carbon nanotubes. The sensor's performance may allow improved non-destructive evaluation and testing, leading to reduced failure rates and greater safety of critical infrastructure.  Because many of the applications involve safety certifications, strain measurements have great societal value in helping to prevent catastrophic structural failures that may claim human life and incur significant costs.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a strain measurement technology called strain-sensing smart skin. The technology uses a sensing layer consisting of single-wall carbon nanotubes embedded in a polymeric host that is applied to the surface of metallic, plastic, composite, or cement-based substrates. After curing, subsequent strains in the substrate are transmitted through the film to the nanotubes, perturbing their electronic structures and shifting their characteristic near-infrared emission in systematic and predictable ways. Laser excitation at any points of interest induces emission the from nanotubes at those locations, and the emitted light is spectrally analyzed to reveal the local strain value. The strain values may be compiled to form two-dimensional strain maps. This method may have a significant advantage over digital image correlation (DIC), the only strain mapping method in common industrial use. DIC requires the specimen to stay under constant observation while the proposed technology does not have this requirement. This means that the proposed technology may be used to measure strains that have accumulated in service (e.g., ground maintenance inspections of aircraft).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes for NSF I-Corps

In this project, a small team of Rice University engineers and scientists enrolled in an intensive I‑Corps program that trained them to assess the commercial viability of their recent technological advances. That technology is a novel method for measuring and mapping mechanical strain in key structural components of infrastructure such as airframes, wind turbines, chemical storage tanks, pipelines, etc. Heavy industries need such strain measurements for testing and maintenance to ensure safe and reliable operation. The newly developed method uses single-wall carbon nanotubes as tiny strain sensors that are applied to the surface of a structure in a thin polymeric film. Subsequent deformations of the structure are transmitted through the film to the nanotubes, which respond with small changes in wavelengths of their near-infrared fluorescence emission peaks. By carefully capturing and analyzing those spectral peaks, the investigators can measure and visualize the specimen’s strain with high sensitivity and spatial detail.  

During the I-Corps program, the investigators were introduced to key commercialization concepts such as identifying market segments, customer discovery, value propositions, partner companies, beachhead markets, customer relationships, pricing tactics, cost estimates, product-market fits, and business models. More than 100 interviews were conducted with prospective customers, suppliers, and industry experts to gain an understanding of how the proposed product could be manufactured and marketed in a commercially viable way. This process revealed considerable differences between market segments and even between companies within one market segment in the willingness to consider employing a new strain measurement method. It was therefore concluded that a start-up company offering the new technology would need a beachhead customer that has high prestige and respect within the engineering community to provide credibility and gain traction with other prospective customers. One particular aerospace manufacturer was identified as ideal for this beachhead role. Following the end of the formal I-Corps instruction, the Entrepreneurial Lead in the project team worked for several additional months to refine the business model and continue the customer discovery process. As a result, the team is planning to launch a start-up company in Summer 2024 to bring their new technology to market.  

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2024
Modified by: Satish Nagarajaiah
